Line_References: Both agents provide comprehensive ABAP-to-PySpark migration validation solutions with robust error handling, logging, and reconciliation reporting. Agent 1 offers superior code organization through class-based architecture and includes comprehensive pytest test suite. Agent 2 provides better production readiness with extensive configuration management and security practices. Both implement core validation workflows effectively.

Details: Both agents address identical migration validation goals: parsing ABAP/PySpark code, simulating ABAP execution, converting to Parquet, transferring to distributed storage, executing PySpark transformations, comparing results, and generating reconciliation reports. Agent 1 focuses on educational completeness with detailed comments and test cases. Agent 2 emphasizes production deployment with environment-based configuration and security practices. Core semantic intent is highly aligned with minor emphasis differences.

Agent 1 uses object-oriented class-based structure (ABAPtoPySparkMigrationValidator) with methods for each validation step. Agent 2 uses functional approach with utility functions and main workflow function. Both follow similar logical flow: initialization → parsing → ABAP execution → conversion → transfer → PySpark execution → comparison → reporting. Agent 1 includes integrated pytest test cases (lines 200-350), while Agent 2 separates configuration from logic. Different architectural patterns but equivalent decomposition.

Excellent syntax validity with proper Python imports, class definitions, and method implementations. Minor issues: variable name '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s' appears to be a token placeholder (line 45-50). All PySpark operations, pandas operations, and file I/O are syntactically correct. Pytest test cases are well-formed with proper fixtures and assertions.

Good syntax validity with proper imports and function definitions. Issues: Variable name 'ABAP_To_PySpark_Recon_Tester.csv' used as attribute access (line 65-70) is invalid Python syntax. Some configuration variables reference non-standard paths. Environment variable handling is syntactically correct. Overall structure is sound with minor syntax inconsistencies.

Both agents demonstrate strong syntactic correctness with comprehensive Python implementations. Agent 1 has superior test coverage and cleaner variable naming. Agent 2 has minor syntax issues but better production configuration practices. Both implement complete validation workflows with proper error handling and logging.

Line_References: Excellent foundation with comprehensive test coverage and clear documentation.
